intro: Cymopterus terebinthinus, commonly known as the gum plant, is a species of flowering plant in the family Amaranthaceae. It is native to the western United States and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces a sticky resin, which is the source of its common name. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed areas. Cymopterus terebinthinus is known for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for various wildlife species.
